results.title: Productivity is people
results.creator_credit: Michael Robertson, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia

results.title: Production systems. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Examines several different case studies on plant production systems. The environment can be manipulated to produce seedlings for retail nurseries, while vegetable seedlings are produced in large quantities needed by growers. Demonstrates hydroponics in a controlled environment being used to grow tomatoes and micro-propogating techniques. Explains how salt-tolerant plants can be cloned, using tissue culture methods to rapidly produce large numbers of plants suitable for use in high salinity areas.

results.title: Production systems. - 1.
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
The principles applied to commercial plant production are studied by the examination of three case studies. The first is pasture management, where with expert help, resources must be carefully managed to ensure the quality of diary produce. The second case study highlights broad-acre crops, a six year cycle of crop rotation and crop diversity to ensure better economic returns. Lastly, the focus turns to modern orchards and their design in order to ensure increased yields and good crop management.

results.title: Production of foods
results.brief_description: in studying the technology and geography of food production, the following points are given attention: the relation of animal food production to plant food production; methods used to produce plant foods and animal foods; and the important function of the soil in all food production.
results.description: in studying the technology and geography of food production, the following points are given attention: the relation of animal food production to plant food production; methods used to produce plant foods and animal foods; and the important function of the soil in all food production.

results.title: Production control
results.brief_description: Dramatises the case for production control methods, showing the need and effect in a medium-sized firm. Co-ordinating and checking manufacturing processes and reliably assessing priorities makes it possible to avoid excessive delays and pressure of work.

results.title: Production 5118
results.creator_credit: Kirby Grant and Wilding Picture Productions
results.brief_description: Dramatizes incidents to provoke discussion on problems of human communication. Unexpressed misunderstandings between Philip Baxter, a typical executor, and his personnel apply to many situations. After each episode, problems and skills in communication are discussed. In an allegorical sequence, Mr Baxter is judged by a signalman and a jury of his mates for failing to give and receive signals. A solution to the problem of communication is offered by the signalman.

results.title: Producing sugar in Australia
results.brief_description: Studies the production of sugar along the northern coast of Australia. Shows all stages of production from planting to refining the finished product.

results.title: Producing a plan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of planning, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Most critical production decisions are made before anything has been produced. Care must be taken to avoid vital errors in such things as shop floor layout when plans are first made.

results.title: Processing the census
results.brief_description: Shows how the details compiled of five million census forms are processed into useful and anonymous information by the Australian Bureau of Statistics during the population census which takes place every five years. No other credits available.
